title: Quick start guide
text: start new data project using galaxias, call: using RStudio, launch new RStudio instance project, following structure: good idea write basic information README.Rmd file first, provides guidance users package contains, well allowed use . point, suggest storing repository GitHub similar. See … advice setting .
code: library(galaxias) galaxias_project("myprojectname") ├── README.md                        : Description of the repository ├── metadata.md                      : Boilerplate metadata statement for this project ├── projectname.Rproj                : RStudio project file ├── data-raw                         : Folder to store source data └── data                             : Folder to store processed data

title: Quick start guide
text: recommend first add data data-raw folder, use script within folder manipulate suitable interchange format (Darwin Core). Let’s assume, example, data looks like : (Note normally ’d import data external file (e.g. using readr::read_csv()), ’ve constructed one example purposes.) recommend using corella package converting tibbles Darwin Core. minimally complete set individual observations formatted using package might look like : Note deliberately includes redundancy. coordinate data useful , example, case ambiguity useful specify text string given information location. Similarly, scientificName field sufficient identify taxon question, adding higher taxonomic information makes identification less ambiguous. Although possible provide data set unrelated observations, structure doesn’t reflect way ecological surveys typically conducted. , example, conducted survey many species can detected , can try: (add code block showing use_events() use_abundance()) (add example refining DwC terms) saved tibble object Darwin Core-specific name, can save using write_csv() data already Darwin Core format, can simply place data folder remove data-raw folder.
code: library(tibble)  df <- tibble(   latitude = c(-35.310, -35.273),   longitude = c(149.125, 149.133),   date = c("14-01-2023", "15-01-2023"),   time = c("10:23", "11:25"),   species = c("Callocephalon fimbriatum", "Eolophus roseicapilla")) library(corella) library(lubridate) ##  ## Attaching package: 'lubridate' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ##  ##     date, intersect, setdiff, union occurrences <- df |>   # basic requirements of Darwin Core   use_occurrences(occurrenceID = seq_len(nrow(df)),                   basisOfRecord = "humanObservation") |>    # place and time   use_coordinates(decimalLatitude = latitude,                    decimalLongitude = longitude) |>   use_locality(country = "Australia",                 locality = "City of Town") |>   use_datetime(eventDate = lubridate::dmy(date),                eventTime = lubridate::hm(time)) |>   # taxonomy   use_scientific_name(scientificName = species,                        scientificNameRank = "species") |>   use_taxonomy(kingdom = "Animalia",                 phylum = "Aves") ## ⠙ Checking 2 columns: basisOfRecord and occurrenceID ## ✔ Checking 2 columns: basisOfRecord and occurrenceID [647ms] ## ## ⠙ Checking 2 columns: decimalLatitude and decimalLongitude ## ✔ Checking 2 columns: decimalLatitude and decimalLongitude [623ms] ## ## ⠙ Checking 2 columns: country and locality ## ⠹ Checking 2 columns: country and locality ## ✔ Checking 2 columns: country and locality [633ms] ## ## ⠙ Checking 2 columns: eventDate and eventTime ## ✔ Checking 2 columns: eventDate and eventTime [618ms] ## ## ⠙ Checking 2 columns: scientificName and scientificNameRank ## ✔ Checking 2 columns: scientificName and scientificNameRank [618ms] ## ## ⠙ Checking 2 columns: kingdom and phylum ## ✔ Checking 2 columns: kingdom and phylum [622ms] ## library(readr) write_csv(occurrences, ".data/occurrences.csv")

title: Quick start guide
text: Darwin Core Archives use xml files store two metadata files; one describes data ownership, second stores ’ structure. recommend using paperbark package manipulate files. build_schema() example build_metadata() example Finally, best build_archive().

title: Quick start guide
text: Darwin Core may unfamiliar format, can useful ‘check’ data common issues. suggest first using check_archive(): Alternatively, can use GBIF ‘validate’ API check data (functional!)

title: Describe, Package and Share Biodiversity Data
text: galaxias R package helps users describe, package share biodiversity information using ‘Darwin Core’ data standard. created Science & Decision Support Team Atlas Living Australia (ALA). package named genus freshwater fish found Southern Hemisphere, predominantly Australia New Zealand. comments, questions suggestions, please contact us.

title: Describe, Package and Share Biodiversity Data
text: package active development, yet available CRAN. can install latest development version GitHub : Load package:

title: Describe, Package and Share Biodiversity Data
text: galaxias contains tools : Create new RStudio project package storing biodiversity data data-processing scripts using galaxias_project(). Create documents describe origin structure data using build_metadata() build_schema(). Zip data sharing publication using build_archive(). Check data consistency Darwin Core standard, either locally using check_archive(), via API using validate_archive(). galaxias part group packages help users publish data using Darwin Core standard. packages : corella converting tibbles required column names paperbark converting markdown files xml.

title: Describe, Package and Share Biodiversity Data

what: Build repositories to share biodiversity data — galaxias-package
title: Build repositories to share biodiversity data — galaxias-package
text: galaxias helps users describe, package share biodiversity information using 'Darwin Core' data standard, format used accepted Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) partner nodes. functionally similar devtools, focus building Darwin Core Archives rather R packages. package named genus freshwater fish.

title: Build repositories to share biodiversity data — galaxias-package
text: questions, comments suggestions, please email support@ala.org.au. Set project galaxias_project() Set project necessary folder structure Construct archive build_schema() Build schema file (meta.xml) given directory build_metadata() Supply metadata file .md format, convert metadata file (eml.xml) build_archive() Convert directory Darwin Core Archive Validate archive check_archive() Check archive using paperbark corella packages galaxias_config() Store credentials API call validate_archive() Check archive using GBIF 'validator' API print_validation() Methods displaying API responses

title: Provide configuration information to galaxias — galaxias_config
text: Note unlike galah, set 'default' provider galaxias; organisation always argument function question. Also unlike galah, galaxias_config() enables store configuration details multiple organisations . Currently, function useful validate_archive(), validating via GBIF.
